body:
For example, in ETS, the random state can be passed to the `get_prediction` method that is called from within sktime to make the prediction intervals deterministic.

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2320#issuecomment-1087330315
agreed! If `random_state` is not already passed properly, it should be.

issue.title: [ENH] AutoETS: heavy random fluctuations in interval predictions - investigate random seed and correctness

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Update by @fkiraly: the below is not a bug, but a consequence of what seems like quite serious random variation in the prediction intervals and quantiles produced by `AutoETS`.

It may be useful to investigate whether:
* a random seed can be set in `AutoETS` to allow deterministic comparisons
* whether the prediction intervals should be something different (e.g., variation predicted added to variation in re-sampling the prediction)
* whether this fluctuation implies anything about the correctness of `AutoETS`

---

**Describe the bug**

Followup from ##2275: AutoETS behavior still seems inconsistent in the 0.11.0 release (ARIMA and Theta has to be fixed now).

**To Reproduce**

```python
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.ets import AutoETS
y = load_airline()

forecaster = AutoETS(auto=True, n_jobs=-1, sp=12)
forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])

# return_pred_int and alpha are disabled in sktime 0.11.0
# forecaster.predict(return_pred_int=True, alpha=0.05)
forecaster.predict()

forecaster.predict_quantiles(alpha=[0.025, 0.05, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9, 0.95, 0.975])

forecaster.predict_interval(coverage=[0.8, 0.9, 0.95])
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/160263672-3deed4ef-41cb-423a-9218-cab02994230b.png)



**Expected behavior**
Would have expected the point forecast to match 50% quantile and coverage = 80% to match quantiles [0.1, 0.9] and so on. This seems to be the case in ARIMA and ThetaForecaster but not in AutoETS.

**Versions**
<details>

System:
    python: 3.7.13 (default, Mar 16 2022, 17:37:17)  [GCC 7.5.0]
executable: /usr/bin/python3
   machine: Linux-5.4.144+-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-18.04-bionic

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.1.3
   setuptools: 57.4.0
      sklearn: 1.0.2
       sktime: 0.11.0
  statsmodels: 0.13.2
        numpy: 1.21.5
        scipy: 1.4.1
       pandas: 1.3.5
   matplotlib: 3.2.2
       joblib: 1.1.0
        numba: 0.55.1
     pmdarima: 1.8.5
      tsfresh: None

</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

body: Do we need to pass the random_state argument to the constructor of Statsmodels adapter ? and then pass that argument to the appropriate methods(methods with get_prediction) of forcasters that interface from statsnmodels ?
yes - sktime should get it through the constructor, and then read it out whenever it is needed internally.
Okay  understood ,can I work on this ?

go ahead!
I would say, pick one estimator and post it here, then get started with it.
What would also help is a list of estimators that need the addition, so we can tick them off.

@fkiraly I checked all the statsmodel forcasters I found sktime/forecasting/theta.py to be similar to ETS but I did not see any randomness in the intervals and quantiles for thetha.py . As I have illustrated below . 

![SS](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81592570/162233065-e90b0291-4860-42a3-a736-f7db9688c0ce.png)
For now I'll work on adding random_state to ets but I'll continue testing the estimators if I get any randomness I'll add it to the list.
Theta, I think, is deterministic, since it computes a least squares fit.

issue.title: [ENH] Add random_state to statsmodels adapter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
#2388 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Adds random_state to statsnmodels so that it can be called internally by any model.
#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

- [x] Have passed random_state to statsmodeladapter
- [x]  Passed it as an argument to get_predictions method. 

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [ ] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [DOC] or [BUG] indicating wether the PR topic is related to enhancement, documentation or bug

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
